reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as well. It's probably treated like on'yomi jukugo because it's attached to things (like numbers!).
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
You've already learned how to read both 持つ and 帰る, so you should be able to read this as well.
The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The 一 portion gets shortened to いっ as it often is.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Be careful of the shortening and the rendaku.

The last time you tossed something into a trash can was the <vocabulary>year before last</vocabulary>. Why? Because you got a trash can with an <reading>auto</reading>  <reading>tossi</reading>ng (おととし) feature. What amazing technology!
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. Here's a mnemonic to help you to remember it: 

Since you have generations of people making up this <vocabulary>world</vocabulary>, think of the rapper generation. What do they say all the time (obviously I don't know anything about rap)? They say "<reading>Yo</reading> yo yo!" (よ).
When everything is in disorder it's finally your chance! You run to the bar, break the windows, and grab all the <reading>mead</reading> (みだ) you can carry.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. That's the case for the first two kanji, but 舌 actually uses the kun'yomi. Not only that, it's read here as じた, and not した.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Add the on’yomi reading for 徒 to the word you already know. Done!
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Make sure you remember ざい over さい, though. Why? Because you got all this debt trying to buy your way into <reading>Z</reading>ion.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The はち part gets shortened as it often does when put into situations like this, making it はっ. The 冊 is all normal, and to the "book(s)." Har!
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The べつ gets shortened to べっ, though, probably because it's a つ and that's what つs do for a living in jukugo words.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

You decide <vocabulary>to add</vocabulary> something and then <vocabulary>to add</vocabulary> something else, and you end up with quite a <reading>qua</reading>ntity (くわ) of things. Just keep adding and adding forever. What a huge QUANTITY you now have!

You learned this reading with the kanji, how nice for you!

However, you might notice that in addition to うめる, there's another reading too: うずめる. うめる is used for the act of burying something or filling in a hole, while うずめる is used when describing the covering or concealment of something, or when burying one's face in something (like a fluffy cat!)
That rail <reading>has</reading> はず to be fixed, otherwise it's going <vocabulary>to come off</vocabulary> again, someone's going to get hurt.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading is the word 大きい plus 順's reading you learned with the kanji.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know 失敗 on its own as well.

The reading is the word 小さい plus the reading for 順.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You decide to put on shoes, and then to put on pants. "Hahahaha!" (は) you laugh. What a ridiculous idea to put on shoes before you put on pants! But you do it every morning, and every morning it makes you laugh. You really crack yourself up.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You take your <kanji>cloth</kanji> and put it on top of your head. It's there because right at <reading>noon</reading> (ぬの) the sun is in the middle of the sky and burns your scalp. So, you cover it with a cloth. Imagine yourself setting an alarm for noon to help you to focus on the noon part.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The reading for 団 is the secondary reading that went with the kanji, though, so watch out for that. If you can figure out the meaning of this word, chances are you already know how to spell it, so carry that over to Japanese.

The reading for this is the same as with the kanji you learned. <reading>とく</reading>!

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You need <vocabulary>to acquire</vocabulary> an <reading>e</reading>lephant (え) for your elephant collection. If you don't acquire an elephant, you'll look like an idiot in front of your elephant collecting friends.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

You're <vocabulary>busy</vocabulary> because you have to take care of your friend's <reading>ice ogre</reading>s (いそが) this weekend. You don't know why you agreed to this, you were busy enough, but now you'll never get anything done running around taking care of these little ice ogres.

The reading is a bit strange. it's the two separate words 恋 and 人 put together, making the reading <reading>こいびと</reading>. Oooh lala. Two words coming together like two people coming together. Rawrs.
You learned this reading with 悲しむ, hooray!
You learned this reading with 悲しむ, hooray!

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Usually when we want <vocabulary>to change something</vocabulary>, we want to make it <reading>新た</reading> (あらた), right? Out with the old, in with the 新た, as they say.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The 布 part gets changed to ぶ, probably because if a food doesn't have <vocabulary>konbu</vocabulary> you say <reading>boo</reading> (ぶ).

This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi of the kanji. You learned this reading for 昆 when you learned the kanji, but you haven't learned the on'yomi for 虫 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Did you know that <vocabulary>insect</vocabulary>s are <reading>Chew</reading>bacca's (ちゅう) favorite thing? He's fascinated by all types of insects, and keeps them in boxes as pets. There are a good few of them crawling around in his fur, too.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Everything is so <vocabulary>easy</vocabulary> for you to do. Why? Because you don't do anything yourself. You ask others. You say things like "Hey, can you get me some water?" They say "<reading>yassah!</reading>" (やさ) very enthusiastically.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're about <vocabulary>to rage</vocabulary> all over the place. You're going nuts. You're going <vocabulary>to act violently</vocabulary>. Then, a calm wizard steps in front of you and mutters "<reading>aba</reading>ra kadabara," (あば) causing you to calm down immediately.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
To remember the reading, just imagine yourself snorting out a sharp "<reading>HA</reading>!" (は) right before saying the phrase: "<reading>HA!</reading> Just as I thought."

The reading for this one, like the meaning, is kind of tricky. It uses two kun'yomi readings that you've learned before. So you have うめ plus ほし, which comes from 干す but gets rendaku'd to ぼし here. In other words, うめぼし. I guess the pickling process has mangled the reading of this word. But you'll just have to deal with it, because this food is as common as it is tasty! 

Also, you might often see this written as 梅干, where the し gets shy or something and hides, but the reading stays the same: うめぼし.

As you're looking at <vocabulary>job posting</vocabulary>s, you notice they're all looking for people with <reading>cu</reading>cumbers and <reading>jean</reading>s (きゅうじん). That's the only qualification they're after, cucumbers and jeans.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Unfortunately, the reading for this is a total exception that you'll just have to memorize, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Just <vocabulary>as expected</vocabulary>, I <reading>saw Suga</reading> (さすが) at the bar again last night… Mr. Suga spends a little too much time at the bar, and we're starting to get worried for him. 流石に Mr. Suga…

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're doing mixing like your <reading>ma</reading> (ま) taught you, which is why when you do the mixing things get done around here a lot faster.

You can also use the level 5 vocab 交ぜる to help you remember as it has the same meaning and reading!
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Your status is <vocabulary>to be decreased</vocabulary> amongst the eyes of the Gods. They decide your punishment is to be decreased into <reading>hell</reading> (へる) where you will live the rest of your days.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that the ほう changes to ぽう. This is because you're trying to subtract <reading>Po</reading>lar (ぽう) bears from the area around you as they're very dangerous and you use a cologne made from meat.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know how to read 意識, though.
The reading is the readings from 焼く and 芋 put together.

The reading is the two vocab words separately put together, just as you'd expect from a body-part related kanji. So, 猫 plus 舌 = <reading>ねこじた</reading>. Just remember that 舌 is read here as じた, and not した.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Pretend you're trying to <kanji>whistle</kanji>, but you can't. All that comes out is air. You make a "<reading>Fuuuuuuueh</reading>" sound over and over, because you can't get the whole whistling thing down. Go ahead and pretend to do that (or do it for real).

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just note that せつ gets shortened to せっ just like many つs do in this situation.

This word has a different reading from the ones you've learned so far, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

After the coyote wrecks your model railroad, he bites you on the head, sending you into an indefinite <reading>coma</reading> (こま).

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

There's an accident you happen <vocabulary>to be involved with</vocabulary> in <reading>から</reading>て class, where it's common <vocabulary>to get tangled</vocabulary> up during sparring. This time you and your partner's limbs are literally in a big entangled mess. Good luck getting out of that.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: <reading>Two du</reading>des (つづ) get <vocabulary>to continue</vocabulary> on. I'm afraid you two ladies are going to have to stay here. This is a dudes only night club.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Uses the same reading that you learned with the kanji. Go ahead and use your <vocabulary>tongue</vocabulary> and say the reading out loud... "<reading>した</reading>."
The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
The reading is the reading you learned with the kanji. Same goes for the repeater kanji.
The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Oh how nice it is to be <vocabulary>young</vocabulary> and to be able to remember that.

若い uses the same reading you learned with the kanji, but the reading for 布 is totally irregular. If you can figure out the meaning, you can use that to remember the reading (since they're the same), but here's a mnemonic to help you just in case:

You're eating <vocabulary>wakame</vocabulary> and you suddenly spot a <reading>目</reading> (め) looking up at you. You didn't know seaweed had eyes!

The reading for this one is a pain. 若 is the same as what you learned with the kanji (わか), but 者 is もの, which isn't what you learned. Think of this: A <vocabulary>young person</vocabulary> does what they want. They don't follow tradition or do anything the way you'd want them to, just like the reading of this word. Also, their actions make you really want to <reading>moan</reading> (もの) because ugh, young people. Get off my lawn.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use one of the kun'yomi readings. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

The best way <vocabulary>to memorize</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to remember</vocabulary> something is to make up a song and play it on your <reading>oboe</reading> (おぼ). Something about playing it makes it so you can memorize anything. You're so talented.

Why in the world do you have <reading>two</reading> (つ) of everything?

All these boxes that are <vocabulary>piled up</vocabulary> are here because you've just moved into your new <reading>casa</reading> (かさ). Congratulations! Now it's time to unpack every single box you've <vocabulary>accumulate</vocabulary>d. Have fun.

The reading is the words 非常 and 口 combined together. The thing that makes this weird is that it's a mix of the kun and on'yomi readings. I guess things get all jostled up when you have yourself an emergency.
